segments.text: Testing, this is an interview with Dr. John Milleth.
Today's date is Wednesday, March 5th, 1980.
This is the second interview with Dr. Milleth concerning the School of Veterinary Medicine.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is our second interview with Dr. John Miloff on Wednesday, March 5, 1980, and the last time we were discussing the years of the 1920s and the 1930s at Texas A&M.
This time I'd like to bring it up to date.
In 1936 you were appointed instructor, and then in 1938 you were appointed assistant professors in the Department of Pathology.
Could you tell me what courses you taught?
And what was the teaching load back then?
Well, I couldn't tell you without looking in the catalog.
But I was the only one in veterinary pathology.
And we had a general pathology course and a special pathology course.
And as I recall, there was a graduate course
but in those days it was not taught very often.
Most of the teaching back in those days was just for veterinary students and they didn't go on for graduate work very often.
So in the main it consisted of general and special path.
That was it.
You remember the first time you gave a lecture
Yes.
Could you relate that?
I remember it very distinctly, but this was not in veterinary medicine.
It was over in biology.
Oh, really?
Yes, because I had been a graduate assistant two years in biology in 1932.
When I had my first class, it was in the anatomy and physiology for...
physical ed students and pre-med students.
And as I told you the other day, Dr. Kelsey in Houston and Bones Irvin, who was in our athletic department for quite a few years, were students.
Same way with Dr. Mac Fattridge.
So I had several men there who later became
MDs and rather prominent people.
So, luckily, the first lecture, the first hour of class was only 30 minutes in those days.
It was only 30 minutes?
A lecture was 30 minutes?
The first hour.
Oh, in the morning.
The first hour in the morning?
No.
The first time the class met.
Oh.
You met for 30 minutes, just to more or less to
find out about your students and see that their cards were there, and to assign a lesson, to name the textbook.
It's more of an introductory period.
And from then on, it was 50 minutes?
From then on, it was a 50-minute period.
Luckily, it was only 30 minutes because my mouth became so dry I could hardly speak.
My first class at Texas A&M.
I had, I think it was eight students in that group.
It was a 300 course.
And it was all my course at $45 a month.
But they didn't give you the introduction, the survey course?
The lower level course?
They gave you an upper level course the first time?
No, I had 341, 342 biology.
Four hour course, physiology and anatomy.
So it was all mine.
I borrowed and bought a few things.
Dr. Ball gave me enough money to buy some histology slides.
I borrowed skeleton, human skeleton bones from Galveston Medical School.
Just here, yonder, and elsewhere.
Physiology, but near physiology alone, a few smoke drums, a few drum chemographs to smoke.
That's all we had.
We went frog gigging at night, caught frogs for nerve muscle preparations.
We had a good time.
The students, well, Bones Irving said, John, that's the best course I ever had in my life.
In general, you thought you were pretty nervous?
I was.
My first class, I was rather nervous, naturally.
Now, all this was before World War II.
Do you remember what you were doing on December 7, 1941?
Pearl Harbor.
I can remember at noon on December 7th, we were having, Ruth and I were having lunch at Miss Maggie Parker's in Bryan.
With old Judge Nunn from Crockett and Mrs. Bernice Claytor, who was in the extension service at A&M.
And the news came over the radio that Pearl Harbor had been bombed.
I remember that very well.
What was your reaction?
Well, my reaction was one of utter dismay because we were told that the Pacific Fleet had been wiped out and we didn't know what was to happen next.
How about your colleagues?
Well, they had the same reaction, but it wasn't long before we settled down.
We registered and so on.
I had to register for the draft, but I was classified 4F because I had had tuberculosis and so on.
So I managed to stay on at A&M and teach.
Well, we had ASTP students.
They were in the armed forces, actually.
And to begin with, then, Dr. Rubin had a commission in the armed services.
So he had to leave.
And I was left alone.
And from then on, I don't know how many veterinary graduates we hired during World War II.
I thought it was a pity.
since we were teaching students who were in the armed services, why the faculty was not put in armed services too.
Because we were kept busy trying to find someone to teach on account of the fact that every time we got someone, they were drafted.
So it kept us in a turmoil all the time.
During the war, we were.
In other words, you wanted to have a commission then?
Yes, I'd like to have had a commission and to have been assigned to teach.
Oh, I see.
And I think if we ever get into another conflict, that's what they should do.
I can't see any reason why you have to keep searching for someone to teach students who are in the services.
Because in the service, if they're teaching, they're certainly in uniform.
And there was another thing, too.

Our faculty members were young people where they just graduated, more than likely, and came right back into teaching just as a gap between then and going into the service, because they knew they were going to be drafted.
They were in civilian clothes.
And here in Bryan, we had Bryan Air Force Base.
And on weekdays or weekends, the streets of Bryan were just filled with men in uniform.
And what do you think?
Here's a youngster goes down there.
He's maybe 21, 22 years old.
And he's in civilian clothes.
Yeah, what are you doing in civilian clothes?
Why aren't you in uniform?
Well, it was embarrassing to them.
I've had that related to me.
You had it related while you were here?
Yeah.
Could you give me an example?
The youngsters who went to town and were criticized for not being in uniform.
I've had them tell me that they just didn't want to go to town, on Saturdays especially.
when the streets would be jammed with men in from Bryan Air Force Base.
So I think if we ever get into another conflict, why, if we're going to continue our college courses within, staff members who are teaching should be in uniform.
That's the only thing to do.
That's an interesting point.
Now.
We had.
The speed-up program, as they called it in those days.
What did that stand for?
You taught every course every semester.
Now, if you can, you just try to do that and try to keep faculty, too.
Yeah.
Every course, every semester.
So that's a choice.
That went on for three years.
Every course, every semester.
And so are there any other ways in which, besides the speed up, are there other ways in which the war affected the school of medicine, do you think?
Well, we had trouble getting formaldehyde for embalming, and we had trouble in obtaining alcohol.
We had trouble in obtaining almost anything.
Sometimes, well, I can recall that we paid as high as,
$15 a gallon for formaldehyde for embalming animals.
$15 a gallon.
Of course, I don't know what it sells for now, but that was a tremendous price to pay for it.
What did it cost normally?
I don't recall now, but it was much cheaper than that old $1.02 a gallon, something like that.
compared to that $15.
But there were people who would like to do a little black marketing.
Oh, really?
Oh, yeah.
Do you know of any examples?
Well, I'm not going to quote any names, but I know one person who would like to have sold me more formaldehyde.
He had it, but he wanted an exorbitant price for it.
But I told him we'd just do without.
But in general, did you find much black marketing during that time?
No, I didn't.
We had trouble getting alcohol.
Our alcohol, I don't know whether it still does or not, but in those days, it came from the state chemist, old Dr. Fraps.
Pardon me for the old.
But Dr. Fraps was head of the state chemistry lab
then, and he was very reluctant to give up the alcohol unless you had a real need for it.
And he put you through an inquisition.
If you went over there for a gallon or two of alcohol, he asked you 1,001 questions.
Mean it?
It was like an inquisition.
Oh, really?
I can remember one person who was over in biology, went there for alcohol.
Dr. Frapps began with that inquisition with him.
Well, this person didn't relish the idea of being interrogated so intensely.
So when Dr. Frapps asked him, what are you going to do with this alcohol?
He said, well, Dr. Frapps,
I'm going to take you down on the Brazos River and get drunker than hell.
Don't you want to go along with me?
They had him up on the carpet.
He had to visit the president's office.
And he was dressed down for being so insubordinate.
That type of a martyr.
And there was another one who went over there.
He said, Dr. Fraps, I have heard quite a bit about you on this campus.
You old SOB.
I don't intend to sit here and undergo this interrogation.
Now, if you're going to give me the alcohol, let's have it.
If not, I'll be on my way.
Well, they had him up on the carpet, too.
And rightly so, he had no reason to say anything like that to Dr. Frapps.
Well, he learned a few things from Dr. Frapps.
I went over there one time with some glass bottles.
So at the end of the interrogation, he asked me if I brought containers for the alcohol.
I said, yes, I have some jugs.
He said, are they crock?
I said, no, they're glass.
He said, well, they're not jugs.
They're bottles.
Jugs are made of crock.
Thank you very much, Dr. Frank.
And then you went upstairs.
Old Dr. Asbury, another one of the old timers on the campus, had quite a character.
You had to take the requisition up to him to get the alcohol.
So he measured it.
He measured it to the cc.
He had a 1,000 cc graduate cylinder.
And he poured the alcohol out of five gallon tins into this graduate cylinder.
He was rather nervous, so he would spill quite a bit on the floor.
Well, the boss says we have to measure it to the CC, and he's just sloshing it over.
He's spilling about as much as outside the cylinder is in it.
But he was another character.
Were there other changes besides the shortage of supply that you noticed during the war?
No, I don't recall.
I know we worked hard.
What about the number of students?
We didn't have too many students.
The student groups fell off quite a bit.
But prior to the war, we had gotten up to a goodly number of students.
I don't know how many we had.
I'd have to go back and
look at my old class roll books to find out exactly the number.
I guess those old roll books are still in the anatomy department.
I left them there.
They were supposed to be part of the property of the college.
In those days, we had quite an influx of students from New York.
Why is that?
They could go to school cheaper in Texas than they could up there.
And Cornell evidently didn't want too many of them.
They required the student to have a year on the farm.
I don't know what else they required, but that kept most of them out because they were from Long Island and Hoboken.
what have you, around New York City, the Bronx.
So we had a big influx of those fellows for several years.
Finally, the board of directors ruled that we couldn't take any out-of-state students except nine students from Louisiana.
And that's all.
When was that about?
When did that change come about?
Oh, I don't recall, but it was way back in there in the 40s.
So I don't recall what year it was.
Speaking of the 40s, right after the war, there was this university, and many universities in this country have experienced a great period of growth.
Well, that's when our growth began.
Yeah.
Let's talk about that.
What do you think were the most important changes?
Well, I think that the most important changes came about in our curriculum.
We began to look at our curriculum more closely.
Well, I would say that from the late 30s on, our curriculum improved and our teaching improved.
In fact, I think that along about
19 and 38, probably.
From then till now, we've been on a gradual improvement.
Why do you say that?
Why would you pick out that period?
Well, there was a period in there from, I would say, the middle 20s on up to about 38, wherein the College of Veterinary Medicine deteriorated.
And as I can look back and see it, we almost closed up.
In fact, when I started teaching in veterinary medicine in 36, it was deplorable.
We had nothing.
Supplies.
No supplies.
Nothing built up in a...

In a department where you're supposed to have a beautiful slide library for histology and embryology, or in pathology where you're supposed to have, oh, examples of nearly all the diseases and pathologic conditions in animals, what do you have?
Nothing.

everything is rack and ruin the old slides well when i went into pathology in 36 there were a few old things there slides of conditions diseases that dr francis and dr marsteller had brought from ohio state with them things that they had picked up along the way well the stains had deteriorated
They were cut too thick.
They were improperly prepared, and so on.
So all of that stuff, instead of trying to teach with it, which was useless, I threw it out, just threw it away, broke it up, put it in the trash, and started from scratch.
Well, why do you say that it started to improve in about 39?
Well, that's when we actually, the improvement
was enough that you could see it by 38 or 39.
To begin with, in 36 and 37, you were striving with everything you had, all the energy you were putting forth to building up a slide collection.
If you wanted to show a student a section of liver, a liver cell, what did you have?
A picture and a book.
And that's about the way it was.
And in pathology, in 35 or 34, when I took pathology under Dr. Wharton, all he did was to give each student, there were 16 students, he gave each one of us five slides of diseased tissue.
And whenever you wrote the slides up,
and turned them in, you had finished your course in pathology.
That is the truth.
So what pathology did we have?

All you did was to turn through a pathology textbook and try to find something in the way of an illustration in the book that looked like what you had in this section that you were looking at under a little old cheap microscope, if you could
find one that wasn't in use.
They didn't have but three or four microscopes.
So I would say that as far as pathology went, I had none when I was studying in veterinary medicine.
Now this was 1934.
He had no collection of material.
He had enough
material to put five slides in an envelope, and when you have decided what these are, well, write them up and turn it in, and I'll give you a grade on it.
We had no formal lectures.
We had no post-mortem material.
He and Dr. Wharton and Dr. Marsteller were at odds.
And Dr. Marsteller would see to it that nothing that died ever went to pathology for an autopsy.
Nothing.
And I can remember that we posted one old mule.
And that's all I saw in pathology.
And I don't recall now what was wrong with the old mule.
He may have died of colic or something.
I don't know.
So actually, other than physiology, Dr. Burns was giving a good course in physiology and a good course in pharmacology and toxicology.
His department, I don't believe, ever fell down.
But the others did because Dr. Wharton
taught 11 courses all by himself.

Now, if you can teach all the courses in pathology, all the courses in bacteriology, including immunology, milk and meat hygiene, sanitary, classes in milk and meat inspection work, if you can do all of that
plus jurisprudence, 11 courses, I believe, altogether that have been broken down into three or four departments now with I don't know how many people in each department.
But here was one man attempting to do all of that.
Well, I don't think his attempt went very far.
I think he gave up.
And I believe that's the reason that he and Dr. Marsteller were at odds.
Well, that and other things, too.
The personal life of Dr. Horton was something else.
When he died in San Antonio, he had been married nine times and divorced, I believe.
But he was... Nine times?
Dr. Wharton was... Nine times?
Well, his father... How could any man handle that?
His father had been married and divorced 11 times, so he wanted to break his father's record.
So he told me.
Anyhow, I was his graduate assistant, and very often, to show you more about the teaching in those days, he might come to me

10 minutes before class time and say i have to go into town would you mind taking this next class i said well what is it and he would say maybe uh general pathology or something i said well what were you going to talk about today well he said just talk about anything you want to talk about because i have got to go to town so
Yeah, I am.
I don't know what he was going to talk about, if anything.
So I have about 10 minutes to get ready.
So you know what they had.
Because at that time, I had had no pathology to amount to anything.
Yes, I had had this course that he was supposed to give to the students.
But I don't know what he was going to do.
Ten minutes before class time.
Here you go.
What'd you do?
Well, you just take a book and more or less read it out to them.
And that's about something.
Why did he have to go to jail?
So he would come.
Well, he was having trouble.
He had had a divorce.
And his wife had been given custody of the two children.
And the sheriff was on him then.
He was, I think Wharton had the children down at his house.
He had taken them down there.
And the sheriff was going to go down there and get them.
And Wharton says, well, if you do, I'll meet you at the front gate.
And you're not going to get away alive.
I'll kill you.
And he would have.
I believe he would have.
The sheriff didn't show.
I believe.
Well, anyway, I think that.
But he didn't get along with Marsteller.
He and Dr. Moore.
Well, I can see that.
Dr. Marsteller didn't want to put up with a lot of foolishness.
And the way things were going, too, in the department.
Horton was a very independent person.
I could talk to you all day about Dr. Horton.
But he, Dr. Horton, actually was a brilliant person.
He had a photographic memory.
He could take a textbook or whatever you handed him and just turn page after page and give it back to you word for word, practically word for word.
Or he would come into class.
This was back in, oh, long, about 19 and 30, 31, somewhere along.
taking a course as an elective.
Dr. Wharton would come in, roll his Bull Durham cigarette, push his big black Stetson kind of over his shaggy eyebrows, get his boots up on the table.
There's something in there.
He'd been out in the cowlots.
You could tell he always wore cowboy boots and never cleaned them.

He'd roll that cigarette with one hand and then strike the match with his thumb nail and light a cigarette and then flip that match way on over yonder somewhere and say, well, what do you want to talk about this morning?
Well, someone said this morning that,
They're having an outbreak of anthrax in Louisiana.
We would like to know just exactly how you would handle an outbreak of anthrax.
So he would spend an hour, and he would give you all of the government regulations, how to handle an anthrax outbreak, and so on, perfectly.
Really?
Absolutely perfect.
But there he is, you can see him with that big black Stetson, pushed down over there and smoking that bulldog cigarette, and talking to the students.
And his feet are up here on the table, and he's in an old captain's chair or something back there.
But he would tell you, he knew.
But it really doesn't matter.
